title: We thought the junglers with instant gapclosers were too reliable
body:
So we nerfed the range on smite so they can't slow you when they're already on top of you beating your face into a bloody smear. 

-Riot Balance Team


This made my night. This logic is so backwards it makes my head hurt trying to figure out how it made any sense at all. You're telling me that the junglers that only have to land a skill shot (or hop to a ward/standard), to literally appear on top of you, are going to be at all affected by reducing smite's range.

The ONLY junglers that this at all affects are the ones WITHOUT ANY GAPCLOSERS. Chilling smite is icing on the cake for lee sin, vi, amumu, and jarvan. For champions like Udyr, Hecarim (ult aside), shyvanna and skarner, the ones with without instant gapclosers, this ult further renders them as nonviable junglers in today's League of Mobility. Make it even more difficult for them to stick to a target.

replies.body:
Cho'gath needed the range on chilling smite to slow down champions to land his Q, that's the kind of junglers rito is hurting here, the extremely immobile ones who rely on the range and slow of chilling smite to gank you.

Meanwhile, the strong junglers, you know, the junglers that were plenty strong before the jungle rework, they are left untouched, they have the tools to gank and be relevant without chilling smite.
I'm just shocked that you had two down votes on something that is 100% accurate and thought out...

> [{quoted}](name=Retillin,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=E0204tXT,comment-id=00080000,timestamp=2015-02-14T19:46:40.979+0000)

Welcome to the internet.

They don't want junglers to be as strong as they are, as the single most important champion in the game until late when the ADC takes over.

The problem is they will be so long as ... ahem... the good junglers have their kits.

So they aren't buffing weaker junglers, or nerfing stronger junglers, but just nerfing all junglers as a whole? That makes sense. Because instant gapcloser junglers will so be on par with the weaker ones now. It's not like the range on smite will effect the weaker junglers at all. Nope. :)

Am I the only one that sees all Riot's balance attempts as, "This is just the first step!" which just keeps hurting those champions in need most while just slowing those on top a tiny bit? How many times can one team fail to grip the major issues and continually make everyone except the problematic champions suffer? Pre-season is supposed to be about big changes and while we got massive jungle changes we got pretty much zero change on the top junglers except the addition of Rek'Sai to the list of champions you're unlikely to run from. So much for going for really big experimental stuff this pre-season hey?
Is that what was really said in context to the smite range nerf?

> [{quoted}](name=Nate the Fox,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=E0204tXT,comment-id=0000,timestamp=2015-02-14T07:36:06.061+0000)
>
> Is that what was really said in context to the smite range nerf?

Meddler:

"One of the reasons behind that change is the belief that Chilling Smite is making skillshot/free targeted offensive dash junglers (such as Lee Sin, Jarvan, Amumu etc), more reliable in early ganks than they should be."

As in, they chilling smite FIRST and THEN land their skillshot that should be dodgeable but isn't because of the smite slow.

That's why the range nerf.

If {{champion:77}} or anyone else needs a buff, fine, but adding a long range slow to kits that are designed not to have one causes serious problems, especially for people who rely on long range skillshots, like {{champion:64}}.  They should be able to miss, and with chilling smite, they didn't.
The problem is that they aren't buffing the less effective junglers and they really aren't directly nerfing the dominant ones.

but they ARE buffing the less effective junglers. {{champion:28}} {{champion:120}} {{champion:113}}{{champion:102}}  {{champion:111}} {{champion:60}}  all had increases to their sustain, team fight potential and/or clearing ability in the last few patches, and more are sure to come
Yeah, in some 6 months perhaps.
It's the fourth week of the season, could you possibly be any more impatient?

Preseason was 4 months long, and the beginning of the season has only shown that we were right from the start about the new jungle.  The LCS is showing that you can only have consistent success on one of four junglers.  You say it is only one month into the new season; I say we are THREE PATCHES into the new season, with no real help for the lesser junglers, and no nerfs to the ridiculously strong ones--the same ridiculously strong ones that have been ridiculously strong for MULTIPLE SEASONS.

That blind guy has been on top for years...I'm starting to think Riot are the real blind ones here.

(but seriously they are just counting their money from #LCSBigPlays and laughing at us)

Those junglers Meddler mentioned are reliable in early ganks BECAUSE OF THEIR KITS, not because of chilling Smite.  That's why Lee Sin, Jarvan, and Vi have stayed at the top of the jungle pool for multiple seasons.  People got tired of seeing Lee Sin in the LCS games LONG before Chilling Smite was ever introduced.

But what happens when a different Smite item made another jungler viable?  They nerfed not only the Smite item, but the champion, too.  Warwick got no such soft treatment, step by step hitting him until he was no longer viable.  He took a huge nerf to the item he preferred, AND a nerf to his early clear speed.

So Chilling Smite maybe needs a nerf; I'll grant that.  So does Lee Sin.  So does Jarvan.  Where are their direct nerfs, similar to what Warwick went through?
Jarvan had his nerfs a while back to Q's knockup radius. Vi had a massive CD nerf on assault and battery a long time ago as well.
Riot is too  pro. They even juke themselves.
Good, maybe people will go back to buying the far superior {{item:3726}}

Nautilus would like a word. And by "would like a word" I mean he's too busy crying softly in his corner to tell you how wrong you are.
Yeah Nautilus has 0 problems in the jungle beside mana costs.

He's still weak to invades and the sorts but unlike amumu he has 2 very different things that make him better: his defensive steroid comes in a burst (a big shield), his Q can be a good escape if you aim it at a far away wall and pull yourself to it.

Amumu uses twice the mana nautilus uses as well.

That is actually why I stopped bothering with amumu even though I've played him consistently for 5 years. His mana problems are so bad without a spirit stone-like item that it just isn't worth the hassle really. (coupled with his other issues of course)
He's still weak early game but invade are rare nowadays and the gromp buff allow him to defend himself in this case. So it's more a weakness than an impossibility to be played.

The fuck are you talking about?  Counterjungling with one of the top four junglers happens in almost EVERY game in the LCS, and a huge number of games in high tier solo queue.

Naut has a slow clear speed, cannot duel any of the top four, and if the enemy jungler counterganks him, it might as well be 2v1 in the enemy's favor.  Amumu suffers much the same problem, being unable to handle himself in his own jungle if he finds he opponent in there.

My bad. I don't talk about LCS games or challenger tier but only about SoloQ mainly because I'm not at this level.

And a lot of people point the fact that tanks are weak in the jungle but it's completely wrong and at any level. It's just that some junglers are Op. Tanks are not much in a weak spot than a lot of bruisers that are not the top 4.

Solo queue, even (or especially) at lower levels, follows the LCS and high tier games.  A lot of people in Bronze, Silver, and Gold learn what and how to play by watching streams, even if their execution is not as good as the streamer.

Tanks, all tanks, lack a fast clear time and the ability to duel.  If they fall behind, they are largely ineffective throughout the game.  Even Amumu, whose ult is still useful no matter what, will be more timid if he struggles early.  Bruisers that are not the top four struggle in their inability to safely clear the jungle.

Yes, if you play 1000 Amumu games over your lifetime, and almost always pick him, you are probably going to do fine.  Even Eve has a path that can clear the jungle fairly safely, and any dedicated Eve main knows this route.  But the experienced specialist is FAR less common than the FOTM player jumping on the latest bandwagon.  The problem with this is that a champion like Jarvan isn't difficult, so it does not take much for that FOTM player to beat even a seasoned veteran of a much weaker champion.

Tanks are weak in the jungle, not because of the new jungle, but because of the relative strength of the top four.  These four champions are pushing almost everything else out of the jungle, and pick rates reflect this.
Nautilus has a 50% healthier clear, better ganks pre 6 and even his 6 is really good. His late is also monstrous, don't try to lecture me I play him a lot.
